div.p: It is easy to play thorough bass, when no more figures come up than in this example. Alas! How happy some will be, that there are so few figures here. To admit the truth, now and then I have to allow people to take breath – otherwise it would turn too sour for them. It could be, however, that in consideration of the supposed advantage, since we do not anymore accept any apprentices in this class, but only seniors, one or the other signature is not written so precisely, but left out on porpose: so that a player sharpens his own judgement and learns to walk without a stick.

Besides, I can say, that in the present rule one has to consider the useful training of a good order of the moving fingers. In this particular case one cannot be suprised enough about the nasty stumbling of the appentices, especially when the bass often moves downwards. This only stems from the the fact, that their fingers do neither keep a certain order nor have pointed-out ways. Every master (the one who understands) does make his own thing out of it and gives three or four rules, through which the pupil should learn which fingers to use up- and downwards in both hands. This all is certainly good and may have as much use as the rules of a skilled calligraph. However, that notwithstanding, with the own reason increasing one does not care at all. But there are only few, who do not choose their own hand for writing, which often is not the same as the one of the master. It's the same with the finger-order on the clavier. As many as there are playing, as many ways of the so-called Application one will find. The one plays with four fingers, the other with five and quite some play almost the same fast with only two fingers. There is nothing about it, as long as one chooses a certain guideline and sticks to it. But that is it: The most are so full of doubts and unfirm about this thing, that they need a quarter of an hour before they come to terms with themselves. Therefore I do not propose any particular order, but I demand, that one accustoms himself to only one way firmly and unmovable through diligent exercise. There is only to observe that in the very common scales, one plays upwards in the hand with the ring and middle finger and uses middle and index for going down. The left hand however makes use of the index and the thumb upwards and downwards of the index and middle finger in an alternating way. I am saying, that this is the common way and teaching, but it is suitable in only very few cases.

Im zehnten und folgenden Tact schlägt die rechte Hand allemahl vor, wo die Pause stehet, solches giebt eine gar angenehme Brechung. Im siebenzehnten Tact aber wird es umgekehrt, und da schlägt der Baß seine ehrbaren Viertel voran, wozu die rechte Hand, mit den Signaturen oder Accorden, auf die vorige Weise syncopirt. Eben. also wird es mit allen vorkommenden Vierteln gehalten, die durch Sechzehn-Theile abgehöst werden, etwa auf diese Art:

Wobey ebenfalls zu mercken: daß alle dergleichen BRechungen um so viel angenehmer klingen, je weiter die Intervalle voneinander entlegen sind: solche müssen wol nie kleiner werden, als eine Quarte. denn die Verhältniß der Tertzen (zumahl in der rechten Hand) klingt gar zu enge, und kann fast nicht gebraucht werden. Wenn demnach im sechs- und zwantzigsten Tact H dur stehet, muß nicht von der Tertz, vielwenige von der Octave, sonder bloß von der Quint in die Tertz, Sexten-Weise, aufwärts gesprungen werden.
